docs.snippet: All Times EDTSaturday, Sept. 13AUTO RACING11 a.m....

A former New York Mets ticket sales executive sued the baseball club for discrimination on Wednesday, alleging in a federal lawsuit she was "frequently humiliated" and later fired by the team owner's son because she was pregnant while unmarried....
docs.lead_paragraph: A former New York Mets ticket sales executive sued the baseball club for discrimination on Wednesday, alleging in a federal lawsuit she was "frequently humiliated" and later fired by the team owner's son because she was pregnant while unmarried.

headline.main: Former New York Mets Female Ticketing Executive Sues Team Over Discrimination

docs.snippet: Timothy Ray Jones Jr., who stands accused of killing his five children, has emerged as a tragically paradoxical figure....
docs.lead_paragraph: Timothy Ray Jones Jr., who stands accused of killing his five children, has emerged as a tragically paradoxical figure.
docs.abstract: Timothy Ray Jones Jr, South Carolina man who stands accused of killing his five children, has emerged as tragically paradoxical figure; court records and interviews show that in years before deaths of his children, he was leading fractured life fraught with feelings of betrayal, anxiety and mistrust, even while working as engineer for Intel.

headline.main: A Fractured Life, a Failed Marriage and 5 Small Bodies in Alabama
headline.print_headline: A Fractured Life, a Failed Marriage and 5 Small Bodies in Alabama

byline.contributor: Alan Blinder reported from Lexington, and Timothy Williams from New York. Kalyn Wolfe contributed reporting from Camden, Ala. Alain Delaquérière contributed research from New York.
byline.original: By ALAN BLINDER and TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

docs.snippet: The U.S.T.A.’s rules for younger players continue to divide members of the tennis community, who often disagree about the best methods for attracting young athletes to the sport....
docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S.T.A.’s rules for younger players continue to divide members of the tennis community, who often disagree about the best methods for attracting young athletes to the sport.
docs.abstract: United States Tennis Assn’s rules for younger players, which include the use of low-compression balls and shorter rackets, continue to divide members of the tennis community; critics say requirements make tournaments more confusing for parents and less profitable and more challenging to coordinate for organizers.

headline.main: Modified Training for Children Stirs New Debates
headline.print_headline: Modified Training for Children Stirs New Debates

byline.original: By MARY PILON and ANDREW W. LEHREN
